Explanation: Explanation: There are four fundamental ways in which noise can be controlled. a) Reduce noise at the source. b) Block the path of noise. c) Increase the path length. d) Protect the recipient. These four noise controlling ways reduce the noise pollution.

Question: 2. Which is the best way to control noise pollution among the four fundamental ways?
Option A: a) Reduce noise at the source
Option B: b) Block the path of noise
Explanation: Explanation: The best control method for noise pollution is to reduce the noise levels at the source. We a noise is reduced at the source tan pollution won’t occurrence in the proceeding steps and thus it won’t affect any organisms.

Question: 3. How can we reduce the noise in industries?
Option A: a) By not using the heavy machinery
Option B: b) By using rigid sealed enclosures
Option D: d) By reduce the production of the industries
Explanation: Explanation: In industries, noise reduction can be done by using rigid sealed enclosures around machinery, lined with acoustic absorbing material. Isolated machines and their enclosures from the floor can reduce the noise pollution at the source.

Question: 4. What is the main source of vehicular noise?
Option B: b) Movement of the vehicle’s tyres on the pavement
Explanation: Explanation: Most of the vehicular noise comes from the movement of the vehicle’s tyres on the pavement and wind resistance. Poorly maintained vehicles can also increase the noise pollution in the vehicles.

Question: 5. Which of the following is a way to reduce the traffic noise in the highway?
Option B: b) Increase the speed of the vehicles
Explanation: Explanation: The path of traffic noise can be locked by constructing vertical barriers along the highways. Proper highway planning and design are essential for controlling traffic noise. Establishing lower speed limits for highways also reduced the noise.

Question: 7. What is the best way to reduce the noise pollution around houses?
Option B: b) Built a noise resistant shield across the house
Option C: c) Use of ear buds to reduce the noise
Explanation: Explanation: To block the path of noise, planting trees around houses can be an effective way. In some situations trees will reduce noise levels up to 50% but to be effective we need a trees barrier that is at least 50 feet deep.

Question: 8. In order to reduce the roadside noise which of the following product Australian Government designed?
Explanation: Explanation: In Melbourne, Australia a special instrument called as a sound tube is designed. This sound tube reduced the roadway noise without detracting from the area’s aesthetics and thus it lowers the noise pollution.

Question: 9. What is the best way to reduce aircraft noise?
Option A: a) By using shield around aircraft
Option B: b) By using quieter jet engines
Explanation: Explanation: Aircraft noise can be reduced significantly by using quieter jet engines. The old engines which cause more noise should be replaced by the new engines which cause less noise. Altering paths and time of day runway is also reduced the noise pollution.

Question: 10. What is used during sleep in order to avoid noise pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Earplugs reduced the noise pollution which can help humans to sleep peacefully. Earplugs are a cheap drugstore purchase that makes humans sleep by barring the noise. Noise canceling headphones are also used while sleeping to reduce noise.

Question: 11. How does a car in good condition can cause less pollution?
Option A: a) It goes in high speed
Option D: d) It avoids muffler chugging down the streets
Explanation: Explanation: The sound of a car without a muffler chugging down the street reduces the noise pollution. Keeping car in good and quiet working order reduces the amount of noise it generates and thus it gives a great impact on noise.

Question: 12. Which of the following way reduce noise pollution?
Option A: a) Turn on the loud devices
Explanation: Explanation: Turning on white noise can reduce the harsh noise. Turn on white noise is a counterintuitive, adding more pleasant noise on top of other noise. For example, the drone of a fan can be a pleasant white noise if you have a quality fan.

Question: 13. Which of the following steps can take by government in order to reduce the noise pollution?
Option A: a) Enforcement of all noise laws
Option C: c) Increasing the number of vehicles
Option D: d) Not to create awareness about the noise pollution
Explanation: Explanation: Enforcement of all noise laws is variable and often subjective. Even where laws exist, municipalities may not have sufficient noise enforcement personnel who are well trained and also a person who is an ability to monitor noise compliance.

Question: 1. When did the Noise Pollution Regulations and Control Rule established in India?
Explanation: Explanation: The Noise Pollution Rules established in 2000. They shall come into force on the date of their publication in the official gazette. In these rules, unless the context otherwise requires, ‘Act’, ‘Area’, ‘Authority’, ‘Person’ and ‘State Government’.

Question: 2. What timings loud speakers shouldn’t use in public areas?
Explanation: Explanation: A loud speaker or a public address system shall not be used between 10:00 pm to 6:00 am, except in closed premises or communication within auditoria, conference rooms, community halls and banquet halls, etc.

Question: 3. When can a person complaint to the police regarding noise pollution level?
Option A: a) When the ambient noise standards exceeds by 10 dB
Option B: b) When the ambient noise standards exceeds by 20 dB
Option C: c) When the ambient noise standards exceeds by 30 dB
Option D: d) When the ambient noise standards exceeds by 50 dB
Explanation: Explanation: A person can complaint to the authority if the noise level exceeds the ambient noise standards by 10 dB or more given in the corresponding columns against any area, make a complaint to the authority.

Question: 4. What is the meaning of silence zone for noise pollution?
Option A: a) Area comprising more than 100 meters around hospitals and educational institutes
Option B: b) Area comprising not less than 100 meters around hospitals and educational institutes
Option C: c) Area comprising more than 100 meters around clubs and commercial streets
Option D: d) Area comprising not less than 100 meters around clubs and commercial streets
Explanation: Explanation: Silence zone is defined as an area comprising not less than 100 meters around hospitals, education institutes and courts. The silence zones are zones which are declared as such by the competent authority.

Question: 5. When did the Factories Act constitute in India?
Explanation: Explanation: The Factories Act is constituted in 1948 in India. Section 11 (1) of the Act stipulates that every factory shall be kept clean, without having any nuisance. The word nuisance may include noise and thus it regulates the workers safety.

Question: 7. Which Ministry published a draft of Noise Pollution Rules?
Option D: d) Ministry of Environment and Forests
Explanation: Explanation: A draft of Noise Pollution Rules was published under the notification of the Government of India in 1999 under the Ministry of Environment and Forests vide number S.O. 528 (E). This Act maintaining noise pollution.

Question: 8. In which year the Motor Vehicles Act came into force?
Explanation: Explanation: The Motor Vehicles Act through various sections empowers a state government to frame rules for the upkeep of motor vehicles and control of noise produced by them. Strong implementation of this Act will reduce the noise pollution efficiently.

Question: 9. One of the efficient ways to control aircraft noise is__________________
Option A: a) Building aircrafts with old technologies
Option C: c) Increase the amount of pressure it can withstand
Option D: d) Constructing aerodromes far away from the residential areas
Explanation: Explanation: The Aircrafts Act has many provisions but none for the control of noise. In this regard it is suggested that aerodromes be constructed far away from the residential areas of a city in order to protect residents from the noise of aircrafts.

Question: 10. In which section, if a person violates the noise pollution regulations, is liable for penalty?
Explanation: Explanation: Any person who violating the noise pollution rules will be liable for penalty under the Act. Section 15 of the Act provides that any person contravening the provisions of the Act be punishable with imprisonment or fine.

Question: 11. What is the db level for heavy vehicles in India?
Explanation: Explanation: Decibel (db) is the unit of noise. There are different noise limits for vehicles as well depending upon the capacity of their engines. 80 db is the standard noise limit which has been accepted by Government of India for heavy vehicles.

Question: 12. What are the ambient air quality standards in industrial area during day time?
Explanation: Explanation: Ambient air quality standards in respect to noise various from one zone to another and it also various for day time and also for night time. The ambient air quality standards in industrial area during day time are 75 db and during night it is 70 db.

Question: 13. In which Act, noise is included as an environmental pollutant?
Explanation: Explanation: Noise though not defined in any statute but it is included as environmental pollutants in Section (a) of the Air Act 1981. After this included noise is recognized as a kind of air pollution and steps are taken to control it efficiently.

Question: 1. What is called when an industry removes water from a source and then returns the heated water to its source?
Explanation: Explanation: Thermal pollution occurs when an industry removes water from a source, uses the water for cooling purposes, and then returns the heated water to its source such as lakes, rivers and even oceans.

Question: 2. Which one of the following can cause thermal pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Power plants can cause thermal pollution. Thermal pollution refers to the degradation of water quality as a result of any process that changes the ambient water temperature. Power plants discharge heated water, which is at least 15 Celsius higher than the normal and it is back into a water body.

Question: 3. What is the effect of warmer temperature to the fishes?
Option D: d) Increase the solubility of oxygen
Explanation: Explanation: The warmer temperature decreases the solubility of oxygen and increase the metabolism of fish. This changes the ecological balance of the river. Within certain limits, thermal additions can promote the certain fish and fish catch may be high in the vicinity of a power plant.

Question: 4. What is the disadvantage of control measures of thermal pollution by passing the heated water?
Option A: a) Water is lost due to leakage
Option B: b) Water is lost due to absorption
Option C: c) Water is lost due to dilution
Option D: d) Water is lost due to evaporation
Explanation: Explanation: Thermal pollution can be controlled by passing the heated water through a large shallow cooling pond into which hot water is pumped and a cooling tower after it leaves the condenser. In both the cases large amounts of water are lost to evaporation.

Question: 5. Which one of the following cause thermal pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Release of cold water caused thermal pollution apart for that none of the above given options contribute for thermal pollution. Many industries liberate very cool water from their reservoirs. This water when mixed up with warm water rivers it creates a misbalance in the water bodies.

Question: 7. How does soil erosion cause thermal pollution?
Option A: a) By making natural water bodies to hold in its normal level
Option B: b) By polluting the water bodies
Option C: c) By avoiding sunlight to fall on the water bodies
Option D: d) By making natural water bodies to rise beyond their normal level
Explanation: Explanation: Soil erosion is one of the main causes of thermal pollution. Soil erosion makes natural water bodies to rise beyond their normal level. Thus, they get more exposed to sunlight and cause thermal pollution.

Question: 8. What is a thermal shock?
Option A: a) Sudden raises of temperature to abnormal level
Option B: b) Sudden cooling of temperature to abnormal level
Option D: d) Temperature change only due to environmental factors
Explanation: Explanation: Thermal shock resulting in a rise in temperature of water bodies. When industries and factories dispose the water into water bodies the temperature suddenly raises to an abnormal level. This acts as a thermal shock for aquatic life.

Question: 9. What is the main effect of thermal pollution to the oxygen solubility in water bodies?
Option A: a) They increase the solubility of oxygen in water bodies
Option B: b) They maintain the solubility of oxygen in water bodies
Option C: c) They reduce the solubility of oxygen in water bodies
Option D: d) They don’t cause any affect in solubility of oxygen to the water bodies
Explanation: Explanation: One of the main effects of thermal pollution is they reduced the solubility of oxygen in water bodies. This less solubility of oxygen in water mainly affects the metabolism of water animals and thus it leads to death of aquatic animals.

Question: 10. Which of the following is the main reason for thermal pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Power plants are the main reasons behind growing thermal pollution. Because power plants use water as a cooling agent for cooling down their machines. This used water is in high temperature and it is released back to the water bodies and cause thermal pollution.

Question: 11. How does an artificial lake help in solving thermal pollution?
Option B: b) It gives a good aesthetic view
Option C: c) It helps to breed fishes
Option D: d) It is used during the summer season where water scarcity cause
Explanation: Explanation: Artificial lakes help in preventing thermal pollution. In artificial lakes, heated water can be stored easily. These lakes are very helpful for normalizing the temperature of the hot water. Hot water will not disposed back to the natural water bodies.

Question: 12. What is called for the useless heat from hot water recycled by industries?
Explanation: Explanation: Co-generation can be helpful to combat thermal pollution. In the process of co-generation, the useless heat from hot water can be recycled and used smartly in many tasks by industries. Thus this process prevents thermal pollution.

Question: 13. Generally how many types of cooling towers are there?
Explanation: Explanation: Generally the cooling towers are of two types they are, wet cooling tower and the dry cooling tower. In wet cooling tower, the heated water gets spread upon the flow directing panels. In the dry cooling tower, the heated water is made to flow in circular elongated pipes.

Question: 1. When can we classify waste as hazardous?
Option A: a) When waste won’t cause any mortality
Option D: d) When waste decompose itself without any aid
Explanation: Explanation: Waste is normally classified as hazardous when it causes an increase in mortality o an increase in series irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or the environment when improperly treated or disposed.

Question: 2. Based on how many primary characteristics we can classified waste as hazardous?
Explanation: Explanation: Waste is classified as hazardous if it exhibits any four primary characteristics based on the physical or chemical properties of toxicity, reactivity, ignitability and corrosivity. In addition to these waste products is also classified as hazardous.

Question: 3. What is a toxic waste?
Option A: a) Substances those are not poisonous
Option B: b) Substances those are poisonous only when it taken in large quantity
Option C: c) Substances those are poisonous only when it taken in small quantity
Option D: d) Substances which work as an antidote for toxic materials
Explanation: Explanation: Toxic wastes are substances that are poisonous even in very small or trace amounts. Some may have an acute effect on humans causing death, others may have a chronic or long term effect, slowly causing irreparable harm to humans and other organisms.

Question: 4. Why chronic toxicity is difficult to determine?
Option A: a) Because there is no cure for that
Option B: b) Because it causes only little problems
Option C: c) Because effects can be seen immediately
Option D: d) Because effects may not be seen for years
Explanation: Explanation: Chronic toxicity is much difficult to determine because the effects may not be seen for years. One of the examples of chronic toxicity is cancer which can’t find immediately. Certain toxic wastes are known to be carcinogenic and others may be mutagenic.

Question: 5. Which of the following have a tendency to react vigorously with water or air?
Explanation: Explanation: Reactive waste is that which has a tendency to react vigorously with air or water. It is unstable to shock or heat, generates toxic gases or explodes during routine management such as gunpowder.

Question: 7. What is an ignitable waste?
Option A: a) Waste which can burn relatively low temperatures
Option B: b) Waste which can burn relatively high temperatures
Option D: d) Waste which don’t produce temperature
Explanation: Explanation: Ignitable waste is that which burns at relatively low temperatures say less than 60 Celsius. It is capable of spontaneous combustion during storage, transport or disposal gasoline, paint thinners and alcohol.

Question: 8. What kind of reactions happens in corrosive waste?
Explanation: Explanation: In corrosive waste the reaction that happens is chemical. Corrosive waste is that which destroys materials and living tissue by chemical reaction such as acid and bases and thus cause hazardous to organisms.

Question: 9. Where we can get radioactive wastes?
Explanation: Explanation: Nuclear power plants are the source for radioactive wastes. Radioactive waste is the output from nuclear power plants that can persist in the environment for thousands of years before it decays and cause hazardous to the environment.

Question: 10. Which of the following is a hazardous substance?
Explanation: Explanation: Lead is a hazardous substance often referred to as heavy metals. Lead is abundant heavy metal and is relatively easy to obtain. Most of the lead absorbed by people and wildlife is stored in the bones.

Question: 11. How do PCBs impact on birds?
Explanation: Explanation: PCBs is one of the hazardous waste that impact on greater extent to environment. These PCBs can cause reproductive failure in birds and mammals. Thus this kind of hazardous waste use must be use in limited quantity with precautionary measures.

Question: 12. Vinyl chloride is widely used in the manufacture of______________
Explanation: Explanation: Vinyl chloride is a chemical that is widely used in the manufacture of plastic. A long continuous exposure in humans can cause deafness, vision problems and bone deformities. Vinyl chloride also causes birth defects.

Question: 13. In order to dispose hazardous waste where there are no abundant lands which method is used?
Explanation: Explanation: The most common methods for disposing of hazardous waste are land disposal and incineration. In countries where there is abundant land available for disposal land disposal is used and countries where there is no abundant land incineration method is used.

Question: 1. Which was the first city to an established system of waste removal?
Explanation: Explanation: In ancient cities, food scraps and other waste were simply thrown onto the unpaved streets where they accumulated and cause various diseases. Around 320 BC in Athens, the first known law forbidding this practice was established.

Question: 2. Why burning waste is not an acceptable practice of solid waste management?
Option A: a) Because it is very costly
Option B: b) Because it requires modern technologies
Option C: c) Because it cause several environmental issues
Option D: d) Because it requires lot of space
Explanation: Explanation: Burning waste is not an acceptable practice, because if we look into environmental or health prospective burning waste creates lots of pollution and it is harmful to both environment and as well as organisms.

Question: 3. What plan should we make to the disposal of solid waste?
Option B: b) Recycling of waste management plan
Option C: c) Reducing of waste management plan
Option D: d) Use of waste management plan
Explanation: Explanation: The disposal of solid waste should be part of an integrated waste management plan. This integrated solid waste management is the method of collection, processing, resource recovery and final disposal of solid waste.

Question: 4. The term ‘Municipal Solid Waste’ is used to describe which kind of solid waste?
Explanation: Explanation: The term ‘municipal Solid Waste’ is generally used to describe most of the non-hazardous solid waste from a city, town or village that requires routine collection and transport to a processing or disposal site.

Question: 5. How many main components are there in integrated waste management?
Explanation: Explanation: An integrated waste management strategy includes three main components they are source reduction, recycling and disposal. All these three types plays an important role in the solid waste management.

Question: 7. Which of the integrated waste management is reduced on an individual level?
Explanation: Explanation: Source reduction is one of the fundamental ways to reduce waste. On an individual level, we can reduce the use of unnecessary items while shopping, avoid buying disposable items and avoid using plastic carry bags.

Question: 8. Which of the following can be recycled many times?
Explanation: Explanation: Recycling is reusing some components of the waste that has some economic value. Aluminum can be recycled many times. 	Mining of new aluminum is expensive hence recycling of aluminum plays a significant role in aluminum industry.

Question: 9. Why plastics are difficult to recycle?
Option A: a) Because it is very hard material
Option B: b) Because it is very adhesive in its nature
Option C: c) Because of different types of polymer resins
Option D: d) Because of different sizes of plastic
Explanation: Explanation: Plastic are difficult to recycle because of the different types of polymer resins in their production. Since each type has a distinct chemical composition, different plastics cannot be recycled together.

Question: 10. How many key characteristics of a municipal sanitary landfill are there?
Explanation: Explanation: The three key characteristics of a municipal sanitary landfill that distinguish it from an open dump are: Solid waste is placed in a suitably selected and prepared landfill site, the waste material is spread out and compacted with appropriate heavy machinery, the waste is covered each day with a layer of compacted soil.

Question: 11. How does organic material in the buried solid waste will decompose?
Option A: a) By the action of oxidation
Option B: b) By the action of microorganisms
Option C: c) By the flow of water
Explanation: Explanation: The organic material in the buried solid waste will decompose due to the action of microorganisms. At first the waste decomposes aerobically until the oxygen that was present in the freshly placed fill is used up by the aerobic microorganisms.

Question: 12. What is called for the process of burning municipal solid waste in a properly designed furnace under suitable temperature and operating conditions?
Explanation: Explanation: Incineration is a chemical process in which the combustible portion of the waste is combined with oxygen forming carbon dioxide and water, which are released into the atmosphere. Suitable temperature and operating conditions are required to achieve for incineration.

Question: 13. Why the recycled paper is banned for use in food containers?
Option B: b) Because it creates a lot of spaces
Option C: c) Because paper can be used only one time
Option D: d) Because paper is very thick and can’t cover the food containers
Explanation: Explanation: Recycled paper is banned for use in food containers to prevent the possibility of contamination. It very often costs less to transport raw-paper pulp than scrap paper. Collection, sorting and transport account for about 90% of the cost of paper recycling.

Question: 1. What is called for the pollution that can be traced directly to industrial activity?
Explanation: Explanation: Industrial pollution is pollution which can be directly related to industry, in comparison to other pollution sources. Due to it’s and scope, industrial pollution is a serious problem for the entire planet.

Question: 2. Which of the following are the largest contributors to global pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Industrial waste which creates industrial pollution is the largest contributors to global pollution which endangers the people and environment. Industrial pollution contaminates the environment.

Question: 3. Which of the following pollution majorly responsible for pollution in the United States?
Explanation: Explanation: According to the Environmental Protection Agency, it has been estimated that industrial pollution is responsible for almost 50 percent of the pollution present in the United States. This industrial pollution affect for ecological balance.

Question: 4. Which of the following is the consequence of industrial pollution?
Option A: a) Increase in the water level in seas
Option B: b) Releases of the hazardous radiations
Option C: c) Increase in the animals in forests
Explanation: Explanation: Global warming is one of the most common and serious consequences of industrial pollution. The emission of various greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, methane from various industries increases the overall temperature of the earth, resulting in global temperature.

Question: 5. How do industrial pollution results in water pollution?
Option A: a) Dumping of various waste products from industries
Option B: b) Taking water bodies places to built industries
Option C: c) Industries which uses all the water from the water bodies and cause scarcity of water
Option D: d) Building of purification unit in the industries
Explanation: Explanation: Dumping of various industrial waste products into water sources and improper contamination of industrial wastes often result in polluting the water. This water pollution disturbs the balance of ecosystem.

Question: 7. Which one of the following is the prime factor towards soil pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: Dumping of industrial wastes contain large amounts of various chemicals which get accumulated on the top layer of soil, resulting in loss of fertility of the soil. Such loss of fertility ultimately results in changes in the ecological balances.

Question: 8. Which one of the following industries produced Sulfur dioxide and flu ash as pollutants?
Explanation: Explanation: Thermal industries produced sulfur dioxide and flu as ash as pollutants. Sulfur dioxide is a colorless gas. In thermal industries a reduction in the atmosphere emissions of Sulfur dioxide produced by fossil fuel combustion.

Question: 9. Which one of the following is a mechanical means of treating industrial effluents?
Explanation: Explanation: Sedimentation refers to the process during which particles suspended in water tend to settle out. In another words sedimentation is the process of depositing sediment. Sedimentation is the building up of layers of small particles like sand or mud.

Question: 10. Which one of the following is not normally a pollutant?
Explanation: Explanation: Pollutants are the contaminations that make the environment impure and which don’t play a role in the maintenance of the environment in balance. Carbon dioxide plays an enormous role in the development and sustainability of all life.

Question: 11. Why industries pollute water?
Option A: a) Because they use water in large quantities
Option B: b) Because they release all the pollutants to water
Option C: c) Because industries don’t use water
Option D: d) Because water is an universal solvent
Explanation: Explanation: Industries cause water pollution. Some industries need water in large amounts, they pollute water during use of it in their process. They release heavy metals, sediment pollution and other pollutants.

Question: 12. Which one of the following is the cause of industrial pollution?
Explanation: Explanation: After the industrial revolution there has been a raising rate of waste from cities to small towns that has affected the life of organisms including humans. The main reason for this is unplanned in industrial growth.

Question: 13. Which one of the following is the main cause of air pollution?
Option C: c) Increase in the seawater level
Option D: d) Increase in the modern technologies
Explanation: Explanation: Industrial pollution is one of the main causes of air pollution. Increase in factories and manufacturing processes both large and small scale, gaseous emissions have continued to compound. This makes industrial pollution one of the main causes of air pollution.

Question: 1. Who prepared the Ganga Action Plan?
Explanation: Explanation: Department of Environment prepared an action plan for an immediate reduction of pollution load on the river Ganga. The Cabinet approved the Ganga Action Plan as a 100 percent centrally sponsored scheme.

Question: 2. When did the Ganga Action Plan launched?
Explanation: Explanation: The Ganga Action Plan (GAP) was launched on 14 January 1986 by the then Prime Minister of India Rajeev Gandhi. The main objective of GAP is pollution abatement of the river Ganga and to improve the water quality by interception.

Question: 3. What is the authority constituted by Government of India for the implementation of the Ganga Action Plan?
Explanation: Explanation: For the implementation of the Ganga Action Plan and to lay down policies and programmes and maintenance of the Ganga Action Plan, Government of India constituted the Central Ganga Authority (CGA) in February 1985.

Question: 4. When did the National River Conservation Directorate established?
Explanation: Explanation: Ganga Action Plan undergoes various changes in its implementation. First Central Ganga Authority later it is renamed as the National River Conservation Authority. The Government constituted the National River Conservation Directorate (NRCD) in June 1994.

Question: 5. When did Phase-2 of Ganga Action Plan started?
Explanation: Explanation: Phased-2 of Ganga Action Plan began from 1993 with the States of Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal, Delhi and Haryana were to implement the Phase-2 by treating 1912 mld (Million liters per day) still Ganga Action Plan didn’t complete its target.

Question: 7. Which is the top board in the Ganga Action Plan?
Explanation: Explanation: National River Conservation Authority is the top level board in Ganga Action Plan, it forms policies and sanctioned approvals. It is followed by Standing Committee, Monitoring Committee and National River Conservation Directorate.

Question: 8. Which state has the highest number of towns selected for Ganga Action Plan 1?
Explanation: Explanation: West Bengal has the highest number of selected towns for Ganga Action Plan with 15 towns. Uttar Pradesh and Bihar have 6 and 4 towns as directives from the Supreme Court. 6 towns in Haryana taken upon for GAP 1 as per as the direction of the Supreme Court.

Question: 9. For interception and diversion under GAP-2, how many schemes are sanctioned?
Explanation: Explanation: The NRCD sanctioned 4 schemes of interception and diversion under the GAP-2. The implementing agencies could complete non till 2000, though stipulated dates for 3 schemes were already over.

Question: 10. Which authority laid sewer liner under GAP-2 in West Bengal?
Explanation: Explanation: Calcutta Metropolitan Development Authority (CMDA) laid sewer lines under the GAP-2. The CMDA entrusted the work of construction of 3 pumping stations at Cossipore-Chitpur, West Bengal to a contractor in 1988.

Question: 11. How many interception and diversion schemes are sanctioned by NRCD in Uttar Pradesh?
Explanation: Explanation: The NRCD sanctioned 51 interception and diversion schemes under the GAP-2. The Uttar Pradesh Jal Nigam could complete only 30 out of 51 by March 2000. Stipulated dates of 17 of the remaining 21 schemes were over.

Question: 12. Which of the following is not an objective of the Ganga Action Plan?
Option A: a) Improve the water quality by interception
Explanation: Explanation: Among the above four options increase the water content is not an objective of Ganga Action Plan. All the remaining three options are the main objectives of Ganga Action Plan. Apart from the above three there are many more objectives are there.

Question: 13. In how many cities Rajiv Gandhi launched the creation of Ganga Action Plan when he was The Prime Minister of India.
Explanation: Explanation: Rajiv Gandhi, the then Prime Minister of India announced the creation of CGA. Rajiv Gandhi launched GAP in 5 major cities along the rivers. These cities included Kanpur, Haridwar, Varanasi and Allahabad.

Question: 1. How much of India’s coastline is vulnerable to disasters?
Explanation: Explanation: India’s coastline is vulnerable close to 5,700km out of the 7,516km long coastline. This coastline is vulnerable to cyclones and tsunamis. 68% of its cultivable area is vulnerable to droughts and its hilly areas are at risk from landslides and avalanches.

Question: 2. How much percentage of the landmass is prone to earthquakes in India?
Explanation: Explanation: Large amount of Indian landmass is prone to earthquakes. 58.5 percent of the landmass is prone to earthquakes. These earthquakes various from moderate to very high intensity depending of the intensity happened.

Question: 3. How many hectares of Indian land are prone to floods and river erosion?
Explanation: Explanation: Over 40 million hectares which is almost 12 percent of land is prone to floods and river erosion. These floods and river erosion cause various disasters for the life f human beings and other organisms including vegetations.

Question: 4. When did National Disaster Management Authority formed?
Explanation: Explanation: National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) was established through the Disaster Management Act enacted by the Government of India in May 30, 2005. The Prime Minister is the ex-officio chairperson.

Question: 5. Under which Ministry National Disaster Management Authority comes?
Explanation: Explanation: National Disaster Management Authority is an agency of the Ministry of Home Affairs. Primary purpose of National Disaster Management Authority is to coordinate response to the natural or manmade disaster.

Question: 7. Who heads the National Crisis Management Committee?
Explanation: Explanation: Cabinet Secretary, who is the highest executive officer, heads the National Crisis Management Committee. Secretaries of all the concerned Departments as well as organizations are the members of the Committee.

Question: 8. What is called for the manuals that identify the role of each officer in State for managing the natural disasters?
Explanation: Explanation: Each State Government has relief manuals which identify the role of each officer in the State for managing the natural disaster, such manuals are called as State Relief Manuals. These are reviewed and updated periodically.

Question: 9. Who released the first Disaster Management Plan of India?
Explanation: Explanation: Narendra Modi released the first Disaster Management Plan of India on 1 June 2016. This plan seeks to provide a framework and direction to government agencies for prevention, mitigation and management of disasters.

Question: 10. When did the Disaster Management formed?
Explanation: Explanation: The Disaster Management At was formed in 23 December 2005. The Disaster Management Act, 2005 has 11 chapters and 79 sections that extend to the whole India. The Act provides for the effective management of disasters.

Question: 11. When was Asian Disaster Preparedness Center established?
Explanation: Explanation: Asian Disaster Preparedness Center (ADPC) established in 1986 as a technical capacity building center. It I an independent regional non-profit organization that works to build the resilience of people and institutions to disaster and climate change impacts in Asia and Pacific.

Question: 12. Where is National Institute of Disaster Management located?
Explanation: Explanation: National Institute of Disaster management is premier Institute for training and capacity development programs for managing natural disasters in India. It is constituted under an Act Of Parliament in 1995.

Question: 13. Where is International Tsunami Center located?
Explanation: Explanation: International Tsunami Center is located in Honolulu, United States. It was created in 1965 by the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

Question: 14. When do we celebrate as International Day for Natural Disaster Reduction?
Explanation: Explanation: Every year October 13 is celebrated as International Day for Natural Disaster Reduction. It was started in 1989, after a call by the United Nations General Assembly for a day to promote a global culture of risk-awareness and disaster reduction.

Question: 1. What are the three R’s that are used to save the environment which includes forest?
Explanation: Explanation: The three R’s which are used to save the environment which includes forest are Reduce, Reuse and Recycle. Reduce is the first step towards effective waste management. Reuse helps in reducing waste that needs to be recycled. Recycle helps in the prevention of pollution.

Question: 2. How many National Parks are there in India as of 2015?
Explanation: Explanation: There are 88 national parks are there in India. In 1970, we only had 5 National Parks. Then came the Project Tiger in 1972, and we have added quite a few national parks after the Project Tiger which are playing important role.

Question: 3. How much area is under the forest cover in India?
Explanation: Explanation: Forest Survey of India published the statistics of forest area of various states a union territory in 2017. According to this statistics 708273 square kilometers of forest land is covered in the country.

Question: 4. Which community of Rajasthan Have religious belief for conservation of forest and wildlife?
Explanation: Explanation: Bishnoi community was founded by Lord Jambheshwar, the preserver of all that’s created on earth. The Bishnois consider trees as sacred, they protect the entire ecosystem that exists in their village.

Question: 5. Which one of the following movement was carried out for the conservation of forests and the environment?
Explanation: Explanation: Chipko Andolan is a nonviolent social and ecological movement by rural villagers particularly women’s in India in the 1970s. It was aimed at protecting trees and forest slated for government-backed logging.

Question: 7. Which of the following is not a principle of Chugach National Forest?
Option A: a) The forest service is governed by many existing laws
Option B: b) National Forest System lands are managed for multiple uses
Option C: c) It provides subsistence uses for rural residents of Alaska

Explanation: Explanation: A set of fundamental principles will guide the management of the Chugach National Forest. It is actively collaborate with interested Native Alaskan tribes, state and federal agencies and individuals in the management of forests.

Question: 8. Which country leads in the producing and consuming of forest products?
Explanation: Explanation: The United States is the world’s leading producer and consumer of forest products, accounting for more than one-quarter of the world’s production and consumption of the forest products.

Question: 9. Which of the following is not the best way to fight a forest fire?
Option A: a) Evacuate from the forest surrounding places
Option B: b) Not using water as a fire suppression tool
Explanation: Explanation: Water is the best tool to suppress the fire. When fire crews arrive at a forest fire, they st up power pumps at the closest water source that they can find, and then they run to suppresses the fire. Water can stops the spreading of forest fire and it suppresses the remaining fire.

Question: 10. What is the full form of JFM with related to Forest Management?
Explanation: Explanation: Joint Forest Management (JFM) seeks to secure the involvement of local communities in management of forests on which people depend to meet various needs like for fodder, firewood, grass and so on.

Question: 11. What is called for the practice of regulating forest resources to meet the needs of society and industry while preserving the forest’s health?
Explanation: Explanation: Sustainable forest management, also known as sustainable forestry is always looking to strike a balance between the demand for the forest’s natural resources and the vitality of the forest ecosystem.

Question: 12. Which one of the following is a branch of forestry?
Explanation: Explanation: Forest Management is a branch of forestry concerned with overall administrative legal, economic, social aspects and technical aspects. Management can be based on conservation, economics or a mixture of the two.

Question: 13. Which one of the following is not the best way to stop deforestation?
Option B: b) Not encouraging for recycling the used products
Option D: d) Eat vegetarian meals as often as possible
Explanation: Explanation: One of the easy ways to combat deforestation is to plant a tree. Using less paper or go for paperless is also an effective way to stop deforestation. Eat vegetarian meals also helps to stop for forestation. Recycle and buying recycled products helps to stop deforestation.

Question: 1. When did World Wild Fund for Nature-India (WWF-India) established?
Explanation: Explanation: WWF-India is the Indian part of the WWF. WWF-India is one of India’s leading conservation organizations. It was established as a charitable trust in 1969, it has massed almost five decades of experience in the field.

Question: 2. Which of the following organization launched an Education for Sustainable Development program?
Explanation: Explanation: WWF-India launched an Education for Sustainable Development program in June 2013. This program including a trainer kit with materials in six languages. The program was targeted at teacher training and educational bodies responsible for curriculum.

Question: 3. Which of the following is the most important human activity leading to the extinction of wildlife?
Option C: c) Destruction of the natural habitats
Explanation: Explanation: Destruction of the natural habitats is the most important human activity leading to the extinction of wildlife. Deforestation of the natural habitats of animals affects the species of complete area.

Question: 4. How can we preserve viable material of endangered species?
Explanation: Explanation: Viable materials of any endangered species can be preserved by a gene bank. Gene bank is an institute that maintains stocks of seed banks, tissue culture and frozen germplasm with certain precautionary measures.

Question: 5. Which of the following vertebrates have the highest number of endangered species?
Explanation: Explanation: Mammals group of vertebrates comprises the highest number of endangered species. One in four of the world’s mammal species face extinction, according to a new conservation report card. Marine mammals face even steeper odds, with one in three species at risk of extinction.

Question: 7. Which year Wildlife Protection Act was implemented in India?
Explanation: Explanation: The Wildlife Protection Act was implemented in 1972. It is an Act of the Parliament of India enacted for protection of plants and animals species. The Act established schedules of protected plant and animal species.

Question: 8. In which of the following states Nagarhole National Park located?
Explanation: Explanation: Nagarhole National Park is located in Kodagu District and Mysore district in Karnataka. It is established in 1988. This park was declared the 37th ‘Project Tiger’ Tiger reserves of India in the year 1999.

Question: 9. Which is the natural habitat of Indian lion?
Explanation: Explanation: Natural habitat of Indian lion is Gir forest, Gujarat. Gir Forest National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary established in 1965. According to 2015 census there were 523 lions situated in Gir Forest National Park.

Question: 10. What is called for a scheme to protect and conserve bio-diversity?
Explanation: Explanation: Bio-reserve is a scheme to protect and conserve bio-diversity. The central area preserves the flora and fauna. The surrounding zone is utilized for research and experiments regarding conserve bio-diversity.

Question: 11. Which of the following is a step taken by the government to protect the wildlife?
Option A: a) Control the population of animals in forest
Option B: b) Proper food facilities to the animals in forest
Option C: c) Deforestation to provide space for urbanization
Option D: d) Various Project to protect animals in forest
Explanation: Explanation: The Government of India took various steps to the wildlife. The major among them is establishing of various projects in order to protect the wildlife. Some of the projects are Project Tiger, Project Rhino, Project Great Indian Bustard and many more.

Question: 12. Which type of wildlife is found in Ganga-Brahmaputra delta?
Explanation: Explanation: Ganga-Brahmaputra delta is a natural habitat for many animals. Prominent natural habitat in Ganga-Brahmaputra delta is Royal Bengal Tiger. Some of the other organisms are turtles, snakes, crocodiles and so on.

Question: 13. Which lake in Northeast India has the world’s only floating National Park?
Explanation: Explanation: Loktak Lake in Manipur has the worlds only floating National Park. It is the largest freshwater lake in Northeast India. Keibul Lamjao National Park located at the south western part of the Loktak Lake is the world’s only floating National Park.

Question: 1. What is the full form of NGOs?
Explanation: Explanation: NGOs stands for Non-Governmental Organization. Non-Governmental Organizations are organizations which are involved in carrying out a wide range of activities for the benefit of people and also for the environment.

Question: 2. In which of the following sector NGOs are playing an important role?
Option A: a) In governing the police force
Option B: b) In framing the policy related to laws
Option C: c) In framing the environmental policy
Explanation: Explanation: NGOs are playing an important role in framing the environmental policy. This policy is clearly based on the welfare of the environment in order to protect it. NGOs insist government to frame the right policy.

Question: 3. When does an Environmental Policy achieve positive results?
Option A: a) When policy addressed to urban issues
Option B: b) When policy addressed to local issues
Option C: c) When policy addressed to international issues
Option D: d) When policy addressed to national issues
Explanation: Explanation: Environmental policies will achieve positive results when they are addressed to local issues and solve the problems of local people. The policymakers should keep in mind the needs of the people while framing the policies and implementing the envi¬ronment-friendly projects.

Question: 4. In which of the following Greenpeace is fighting against?
Explanation: Explanation: Commercial Whaling has resulted in the decline of the world’s whale population. In order to stop commercial whaling, Greenpeace is working. Greenpeace is fighting against commercial whaling. Through political work public outreach and by adopting non¬violent direct, action against the whalers at sea.

Question: 5. Why Greenpeace is opposing for genetic engineering?
Option A: a) Because it causes genetic pollution
Option B: b) Because it increase the health of organisms
Option C: c) It completely saves the forest
Option D: d) It contributes for better environment
Explanation: Explanation: Genetic engineering enables the creation of plants, animals and micro-organisms through the manipulation of genes. The organisms, which are produced through genetic engineering when interbred with the natural organisms lead to new environments leads to genetic pollution.

Question: 7. Why Greenpeace oppose the use of nuclear power?
Option A: a) Because nuclear power increase the environment rapidly
Option B: b) Because nuclear power plant abolishes the disasters
Option C: c) Because there is no disadvantages in nuclear power
Option D: d) Because it releases harmful radiations
Explanation: Explanation: Greenpeace are against the use of nuclear power as its use has never been peaceful. Radiation released into the environment through the nuclear tests has led to the contamination of soil, air, rivers, and oceans, causing cancer and other diseases in people.

Question: 8. When did Greenpeace founded?
Explanation: Explanation: Greenpeace was founded in 1971 to oppose US nuclear testing in Alaska. The organization has fought to protect the endangered species, stop the dumping of hazardous waste, and strengthen national and international laws that regulate environmental affairs.

Question: 9. Where is the WWF International located?
Explanation: Explanation: The WWF International is located at Gland in Switzerland. It is an international non-governmental organization founded in 1961. The motto of WWF is “Building a future in which people live in harmony with nature”.

Question: 10. When did the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS) founded?
Explanation: Explanation: BNHS was founded in 1883, is recog¬nized as one of the foremost conservation research organizations in the world. It aims to collect data on the specimens on natural history throughout the Indian sub-continent.

Question: 11. What is the full form of CYWEN?
Option A: a) Club of Youth Working for Environment
Option B: b) Council of Youth Working for Environment
Option C: c) Club of Youth Working for Employment
Option D: d) Council of Youth Working for Employment
Explanation: Explanation: Club of Youth Working for Environment (CYWEN) is a youth group supported by the Centre for Environment Education, Ahmadabad, India. CYWEN has members between the ages of 15 and 23 years.

Question: 12. Which year Green Coalition founded?
Explanation: Explanation: Green Coalition is an independent non-governmental advocacy organization founded in the year 2000. It is dedicated to improve public health standards, protecting the environment and promoting sustainable development & ethical business.

Question: 13. Which NGO has the mission as “Conserve the lands and waters on which all life depends”?
Explanation: Explanation: The Natural Conservancy is a charitable environmental organization, headquartered in Virginia, United State. It focuses on conserving land and species around the world and has over 119 million acres of land worldwide.

Question: 1. Which one of the following issues Environmental Policy is mainly concerned?
Explanation: Explanation: Environmental Policy mainly concerns with environmental issues. These issues include air and water pollution, waste management, maintenance of biodiversity, waste management, the protection of wildlife and endangered species.

Question: 2. When did Indian Forest Act established?
Explanation: Explanation: Indian Forest Act is established in 1927 under British rule. Under this Act developed procedures for setting up and protection of forests which are reserved, protected forests and village forests are the protected area.

Question: 3. In 1972 which Act formed in India to protect the wildlife of India?
Explanation: Explanation: Wildlife Protection Act was established in 1972 in India to protect the wildlife. Apart from this, there are many things this Act looks like formalization of national parks, wildlife sanctuaries, conservational reserves and community reserves.

Question: 4. Which is the only state in India where Wildlife protection Act, 1972 not applicable?
Explanation: Explanation: Wildlife Protection Act provides for the protection of wildlife animals, birds and plants. This Act extends to whole of India, except the State of Jammu and Kashmir which has its own wildlife act known as “The Jammu and Kashmir Wildlife Act”.

Question: 5. Under which domain 7th five year plan helped in the protection of environment?
Explanation: Explanation: Under the domain of Environmental Protection Act, 1986 7th five year plan helped in the protection of environment. It is a legislation which signifies the central governments determination to take effective steps to protect the environment.

Question: 7. What is the full form of PIL?
Explanation: Explanation: Public Interest Litigation is directly filed by an individual or group of people in the Supreme Court. It is a new legal horizon in which court of law can initiate and enforce action to serve and secure significant public interest.

Question: 8. When did Wildlife Conservation Strategy established?
Explanation: Explanation: Wildlife Conservation Strategy established in 2002. According to this policy wildlife and forests shall be declared priority sector at the national level for which funds be earmarked and it also deals with no commercial mono-culture to replace natural forests.

Question: 9. To which government the Ministry of Environment and Forests is the nodal agency?
Explanation: Explanation: The Ministry Of Environment and Forests is the nodal agency in the administrative structure of the Central Government.  It works for the planning, promotion, co-ordination and overseeing the implementation of environmental and forestry programs.

Question: 10. When did the “Policy Statement for Abatement of Pollution” adopted?
Explanation: Explanation: The Policy Statement for Abatement of Pollution adopted in 1992. The objective is to integrate environmental considerations into decision-making at all levels. To achieve these steps to be taken to prevent pollution at source, encourage, develop and apply the best available practicable technical solutions.

Question: 11. Who adopted the technique of public interest litigation for the cause of environmental protection in many cases in India?
Explanation: Explanation: The Indian judiciary adopted the technique of public interest litigation for the cause of environmental protection in many cases. The Supreme Court & High Courts shaded the inhibitions against refusing strangers to present the petitions on behalf of poor and ignorant individuals.

Question: 12. What is the result of PIL that is applied in Rural Litigation and Entitlement Kendra vs. State of U.P?
Option A: a) The Supreme Court prohibited the continuance of mining operations
Option B: b) The Supreme Court allows continuance of mining operations
Option C: c) The Supreme Court withheld the judgment to 2020
Option D: d) The Supreme Court asked the opinion of Central Government
Explanation: Explanation: In the area of environmental protection, PIL has proved to be an effective tool. In Rural Litigation and Entitlement Kendra vs. State of Uttar Pradesh. The Supreme Court prohibited the continuance of mining operations terming it to be adversely affecting the environment.

Question: 13. The decision of the Supreme Court in the PIL of Subhash Kumar vs. State of Bihar is _______________
Explanation: Explanation: The judiciary has used the tool of PIL quite effectively for the cause of environmental protection. But the judiciary has shown wisdom in denying false petitions seeking to advance private interests through PIL as evident from the decision of the Supreme Court in Subhash Kumar vs. State of Bihar.

Question: 1. What is called for the collection of rainwater for use?
Explanation: Explanation: Rainwater harvesting is a technique of collection and storage of rainwater into natural reservoirs or tanks. Rainwater can be collected from rivers, roofs and in many places. The stored water can be used in needy situation.

Question: 2. What is the name of the process to clean water using filters?
Explanation: Explanation: Purification of water is the process of removing undesirable chemicals, biological contaminants and gases from water. Water filter, the device uses small scale quality improvement clean the water for domestic purposes.

Question: 3. What is called for the method of removing dust and other particles from water using filters?
Explanation: Explanation: Filtration is a process that removes particles from suspension in water. Removal of particles takes place by a number of mechanisms that include straining, flocculation, surface capture and more types.

Question: 4. Which one of the following is the best way to conserve water?
Option A: a) Taking shower with less water
Option B: b) Taking shower with more water
Option D: d) Using other liquids instead of water for shower
Explanation: Explanation: Using less water in shower save water and it also saves time for shower. Various methods like installation of a low-flow showerhead, turning off the tap when not using, spending less time in shower can conserve water efficiently.

Question: 5. What is the gallon to use in new toilets according to Federal plumbing standards?
Explanation: Explanation: Old toilets can use 3.5, 5, or even up to 7 gallons of water with every flush. Federal plumbing standards now specify that new toilets can only use up to 1.6 gallons per flush and high efficiency toilets that use up to 1.28 gallons.

Question: 7. How many methods of rainwater harvesting are there?
Explanation: Explanation: There are two ways of harvesting rainwater, 1. Surface runoff harvesting: In urban area rainwater flows away as surface runoff, this runoff can be used for recharging aquifers. 2. Roof top rainwater harvesting: It is a system of catching rainwater where it falls.

Question: 8. How can we increase the water efficient irrigation system?
Option A: a) By pouring unnecessary water to the land
Option B: b) By not supplying adequate water
Option C: c) By applying drip irrigation method
Explanation: Explanation: Drip irrigation is a method of controlled irrigation in which water is slowly delivered to the root system of multiple plants. Drip irrigation increases the water efficient irrigation system and hence it is very helpful in water conservation.

Question: 9. What are the two main types of drip irrigation?
Option A: a) Surface and Subsurface drip irrigation
Option B: b) Under and Subsurface drip irrigation
Option C: c) Top and Surface drip irrigation
Option D: d) Top and Under drip irrigation
Explanation: Explanation: Surface drip irrigation and subsurface drip irrigation are the two main types of drip irrigation. In surface drip irrigation the water is delivered to the surface of the soil directly above the root system of the plants. In subsurface drip irrigation the water is applied directly to the root system.

Question: 10. Why should people implement rainwater harvesting?
Option A: a) In order to play with the water
Option B: b) In order to use during scarcity of water
Option C: c) In order to pour the rain water directly to the sewage
Option D: d) In order to time pass
Explanation: Explanation: Rainwater harvesting helps to store the rain water and it can be used during the scarcity of water. We can use as per convince either directly or for recharging groundwater as the rain falling on the surface to flow away fast.

Question: 11. Which one of the following is the benefit of rainwater harvesting?
Option B: b) Provide a lot of water to play
Option D: d) Decrease the ground water level
Explanation: Explanation: Rainwater harvesting helps for flood mitigation. Appropriate designed recharges in open public spaces will help to keep the roads from flooding. When water is not allowed to leave the premises there is less chance for choking up of the roads.

Question: 12. Which one of the following is an effective way of conserving water?
Option C: c) Always turn on the taps
Option D: d) Boil the water when there is no need
Explanation: Explanation: Eat less meat is one of the effective ways of conserving water. Rearing animals for meat and dairy is incredibly water intensive. By cutting down on the amount of meat consume we can save water drastically.

Question: 13. What is called for an area surrounding a body of water in which that body of water is subject to?
Explanation: Explanation: Watersheds include groundwater flow as well slowly flows through deep soil. For example, if a river is flowing through a city, its watershed would be the surrounding land that is sloped towards the river including forests.

Question: 1. Environmental ethics belongs to which part?
Explanation: Explanation: Environmental ethics is the part of environmental philosophy. It considers extending the traditional boundaries of ethics from solely including humans to including environment which are of many organisms.

Question: 2. On what Marshall’s category of conservation ethics valid?
Explanation: Explanation: Marshal’s category of conservation ethics is an extension of use value into the biological world. It focuses only on the worth of the environment in terms of its usefulness or utility to humans only in this situation it is valid.

Question: 3. According to anthropocentrism who are more important?

Explanation: Explanation: Peter Vardy distinguished between two types of anthropocentrism they are strong and weak anthropocentrism. Question: 5. Who coined the term “Environmental Pragmatism”?

Question: 7. Who is the dominant species in the planet according to human centered environmental worldviews?

Question: 8. Which one of the following is not an ethical guideline?

Question: 9. What is the main reason environmental destruction?

Question: 11. When was first earth day celebrated?

Question: 12. Which one of the following is the major environmental issue?

Question: 13. The common property of rural communities has increasingly been used to supply the needs of the ______________

Explanation: Explanation: The Kyoto Protocol Is an international treaty that commits to reducing greenhouse gas emission. It was adopted in Kyoto, Japan, On December 11, 1997. It later on February 16, 2005 it entered into forces.

Question: 8. When is the first commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol expired?

Question: 9. When did the Montreal Protocol entered into force?
Explanation: Explanation: The Montreal Protocol is an international treaty on substances that depleting the ozone layer and it is designed to protect the ozone layer. The Montreal Protocol was agreed on 16 September 187 and entered into force on 1 January 1989.

Question: 10. What are the substances present in the ozone layer depleting substances controlled by the Montreal Protocol?
Explanation: Explanation: All the ozone layer depleting substances controlled by the Montreal Protocol contain either chlorine or bromine. Some ozone depleting substances are not yet controlled by the Montreal Protocol for example nitrous oxide.

Question: 11. Why hydrofluorocarbons are no harm to the ozone layer?

Explanation: Explanation: Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) are not harm to the ozone layer because unlike CFCs they do not contain chlorine in it. Question: 12. Which Amendment was agreed to phase down HFCs under the Montreal Protocol?

Question: 13. Which one of the following is the objective of Kyoto Protocol?

Question: 1. Which one of the following cause acid rain?
Explanation: Explanation: Acid rain is mainly caused due to a result of air pollution. When any type of fuel is burnt, lots of different chemicals are produced. Some of the gases react with tiny droplets of water. This rain from clouds forms acid rain.

Question: 2. What are two acids formed when gases react with the tiny droplets of water in clouds?
Option A: a) Sulphuric acids and nitric acid

Question: 3. What is the nature of acid rain?
Explanation: Explanation: The nature of acid rain is corrosive. This corrosive nature of acid rain produces many forms of environmental damages. It affects rivers, vegetation, soil and organisms. Acid rain is known to cause widespread environmental damage.

Question: 5. What is the result of acid rain when it falls into water bodies?
Option C: c) The water increase its nutrients value
Option D: d) The water increase its level
Explanation: Explanation: When acid rain that falls or flows as water to reach rivers, lakes, wetlands and other water bodies causes the water in them to become acidic. This affects plant and animal life in aquatic ecosystems.

Option D: d) Decrease in the emission of hydrochloride and phosphate

Explanation: Explanation: Acid rain and dry acid deposition damage buildings. The acid corrodes the materials causing extensive damage and ruins historic buildings. For instances the Tai Mahal in India have been affected by acid rain.

Explanation: Explanation: Acidity is measured using a scale called the pH scale. This scale goes from 0 to 14. 0 is the most acidic and 14 is the most alkaline. Acid rain is much weaker than the string acids, it’s never acidic enough to burn the skin.

Question: 12. Who was the first to use the phrase “Acid Rain”?
Explanation: Explanation: The phrase acid rain was first used in 1852 by Robert Angus Smith, who was a Scottish chemist. In his investigation of rainwater chemistry near industrial cities in England and Scotland he termed the phrase acid rain for the very first time.

Question: 13. When was the “Clean Air Act” in United States came into force?

Question: 11. Approximately how many percentage of electricity produced by nuclear power in the world?
Explanation: Explanation: Approximately 17% of electricity produced by nuclear power in the world. Nuclear power is being used worldwide for the generations of electricity. With numerous harm effects of nuclear power the main advantage is to produce electricity from nuclear power.

Question: 12. Which is the main source of nuclear radiations?

Question: 10. Which is the first crocodile conservation breeding centre in Asia?

Question: 13. When did the Zoological Survey of India established?

Question: 1. When did the Environmental Assessment Institute which is the independent body under the Danish Ministry of the Environment established?

Question: 2. Which institute in Sweden has the motto as “Bridging Science and Policy”?

Question: 5. Who founded Yale School of Forestry and Environmental studies?

Question: 1. Which of the following are moral principles that describe certain standards of human behavior and are regularly protected as legal rights?
Explanation: Explanation: Human rights are rights inherent to human beings, whatever our place of residence, origin, nationality, sex, religion, language or any other status. These rights are all interrelated, interdependent and indivisible.

Question: 2. When did the Universal Declaration of Human Rights created?
Explanation: Explanation: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly at its third session on 10 December 1948. It was adopted as Resolution 217 at the Palais de Chaillot in Paris, France.

Question: 3. Which is the world’s first charter of human rights?
Explanation: Explanation: The Cyrus Cylinder which was created by King Cyrus the Great, it is the world’s first charter of human rights. Question: 4. Which one of the following played an important role in international human rights law?

Question: 13. When did the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) of India constituted?

Question: 1. To which of the following disease HIV virus leads to?
Explanation: Explanation: HIV is the virus that leads to AIDS. People can have HIV for years without having AIDS. Being infected with HIV does not mean suffering from AIDS. People with HIV who start treatment early in their infection, stay on treatment can prevent the disease from progressing to AIDS.

Question: 2. What is the full form of HIV?
Explanation: Explanation: HIV stands for Human immunodeficiency virus. HIV is a virus spread through certain fluids in body that attacks the body’s immune system. If HIV is left untreated, it damaged the immune system over certain period.

Question: 3. Which cells are destroyed by HIV?
Explanation: Explanation: HIV attacks the immune system, specially the CD4 cells, often called T-helper cells and makes copies inside these cells. As HIV destroys more CD4 cells and makes more copies of itself, it gradually breaks down a person’s immune system.

Question: 4. Which is the second most common way of spreading HIV?
Option A: a) Sexual intercourse with HIV infected
Option D: d) From infected mother to child
Explanation: Explanation: Sharing needles is the second most common way that HIV is spreading. Sexual intercourse with HIV infected is the most common way of HIV spreading. Any person who shares needles with someone who is HIV positive is at risk for HIV.

Question: 5. What is the full form of AIDS?
Explanation: Explanation: AIDS stands for Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome. AIDS is the most severe phase of HIV infection. People with Aids have such badly damaged immune systems. That immune system gets an increase number of severe illness.

Question: 7. How many stages are there in HIV infection?
Explanation: Explanation: There are three stages of HIV infection those are, a) acute HIV infection, b) clinical latency, and c) acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). People living with HIV may progress through these stages at different rates, depending on a variety of factors including their genetic makeup.

Question: 8. What is the symbol of HIV-positive people?
Explanation: Explanation: The red ribbon is the symbol for solidarity with HIV-positive people and for those who are living with AIDS. HIV and Aids have a great impact on society as an illness and as a source of discrimination.

Question: 9. How many clinical staging systems are used to classify HIV and HIV related disease for surveillance purposes?
Explanation: Explanation: Two main clinical staging systems are used to classify HIV and HIV related disease for surveillance purpose. Those two clinical staging systems are the WHO disease staging system for HIV infection and disease and the CDC classification system for HIV infection.

Question: 10. When did the World Health Organization first proposed a definition for AIDS?
Explanation: Explanation: The World Health Organization first proposed a definition for AIDS in 1986. After that, the WHO classification has been updated and expanded several times, with the most recent version which published in 2007.

Question: 11. What is India’s position in HIV infected in the world?
Explanation: Explanation: India has the third largest HIV epidemic in the world due to its large population size. India’s epidemic is concentrated among key affected population which also includes sex workers, gay sex and for transgender.

Question: 12. Which body is responsible for formulating policy and implementing programs for the prevention and control of HIV in India?

Question: 13. In which country AIDS was first clinically observed?
Explanation: Explanation: AIDS was first clinically observed in 1981 in the United States. The starting cases were a cluster of injecting drug users and homosexual men. Soon thereafter many more cases of Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP) and Kaposi’s sarcoma (KS) emerged in the United States.

Question: 8. Which one of the following is a result of high exposure of radiation?

Explanation: Explanation: High doses of radiation can be harmful or even it cause fatal to humans and it also damages environment. Doses above 100 rems usually cause the first signs of radiation. Loss of white blood cells happens due to more exposure to radiation.

Question: 9. How do pollutants reach humans?
Option C: c) Pollutants never reach to humans
Option D: d) There is nothing called pollutants
Explanation: Explanation: Pollutants reach humans through the food we eat, the water we drink, and the air we breathe and endanger our health in both immediate and long lasting ways. This pollutants cause various problems to human’s health and also to environment.

Question: 10. How many percentage of water approximately present in human body?
Explanation: Explanation: The human body is mostly consists of 70% of water. Only 2.5% of water on the planet is drinkable and it becomes clear since our body consist of 70% water protecting our water supply is so important.

Question: 11. The current rates of disease are increasing at alarming speeds and most are closely linked with known____________________

Explanation: Explanation: Since World War 2 family planning programs with either major or minimal government involvement have been initiated in most of the countries. This is due to the relatively rapid growth of the populations of some countries.

Question: 2. Which one of the following is the main target of family welfare programs?

Question: 4. Which one of the following is the activity of the Family Welfare Programme?

Explanation: Explanation: Intrauterine device (IUD) is one of the main programmes of the Family Welfare programme. IUD program leads to a big decline in teen pregnancies and it also decreases the rate of abortions.

Question: 5. What is the main aim of Janani Suraksha Yojana which is the programme by the Family Welfare programme?

Question: 7. When did Janani Suraksha Yojana launched?

Question: 8. Which is the first country to initiate a Family Planning program in the world?
Explanation: Explanation: India is the first country to initiate a Family Planning program in the world. In India family planning program is launched in 1952. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is the government unit responsible for formulating and executing Family Planning in India.

Question: 9. When the Family Planning Insurance Scheme was introduced?
Explanation: Explanation: Family Planning Insurance Scheme (FPIS) was introduced on 29 November 2005. It was introduced with Oriental Insurance Company to take care of cases of failure of sterilization or death resulting from sterilization.

Question: 10. Which is the first State in India to recognize the basic relevance of family planning to nation planning?
Explanation: Explanation: Tamil Nadu is the first Indian State to recognize the basic relevance of family planning to national planning. It was given national awards for outstanding work in family planning for many times. Hence Family Planning is successfully continuing in Tamil Nadu.

Question: 11. Why is family planning important?

Explanation: Explanation: Family planning is important for every sexually active adult to consider birth control issues. This is not only for the purpose of preventing unwanted pregnancies, but also to plan the timing of conception for unwanted pregnancies.

Question: 12. In a Hormonal method of family planning, maximum how many hormones are included?
Explanation: Explanation: There is a wide variety of family planning options available. In Hormonal method is one of the family planning options. These include maximum of two hormones, namely estrogen and progestin, or only progestin.

Question: 13. What is Natural Family Planning?

Option B: b) Not having sexual intercourse in any time

Option D: d) Having sexual intercourse with the help of contraceptives
